text: hey everybody thomas joseph here and
today we are talking corn bread now
we've received a lot of comments from
you guys asking us for the perfect
cornbread recipe because your corn bread
at home is either turning out to dry and
crumbly or if too dense and chewy today
i have a great recipe to share with you
and i think the best part about this
recipe is that you can customize it by
adding in some different mixes so let's
get started here with probably the key
ingredient and that is cornmeal that's
gonna make a really great cornbread I
have a very flavorful stone-ground
cornmeal here and if you guys remember
we did a video about cornmeal and the
different types and the different grinds
this is a fine grind and it's stone
ground like I said before and you can
really tell it's stone ground because it
has a slight variation in texture there
are some granules of corn that are a
little bit more coarse and then there
are powdery grains of cornmeal and this
variation in size is a key
characteristic of stone-ground cornmeal
now to this I'm gonna add 1 cup of
all-purpose flour a little bit of sugar
I have a quarter of a cup of granulated
sugar and sugar what it does is it helps
to create a tender cornbread and it also
gives a slight sweetness which i think
is important when you're making a
cornbread you want to have a little bit
of sweetness there and to this I'm gonna
add some salt one and a half teaspoons
of coarse salt we always use coarse salt
here at Martha Stewart Living so if you
don't have coarse salt at home and you
only have fine salt you want to be
careful and use less salt so that it
equals out so that it doesn't create too
salty of a cornbread I'm going to add
some baking powder one and a half
teaspoons of baking powder baking powder
is typically sold in the United States
as double-acting that means that it
Levin's at two different stages during
the process of making and baking and a
half a teaspoon of baking soda and the
baking soda here is going to react with
any of the acidic ingredients in this
batter and help to leaven it even
and the acidic component I'm using is
buttermilk this is the dairy that I'm
using so if you didn't have buttermilk
at home and you needed a quick
substitute we did a whole video on this
you could take regular whole milk and
add a little bit of vinegar to it to
acidify it you could water down some
yogurt or sour cream so I have 1 cup of
buttermilk and to that I'm gonna add 2
whole eggs and these are room
temperature eggs guys again we're making
a quick bread today so these ingredients
are all going to be room temperature it
will create a nice smooth batter and
that batter will then bake up nice and
evenly in the oven and will give you a
good texture in the final baked good
then I add these 2 eggs right to my
buttermilk whisk them up a little bit
breaking them up and a half a stick of
unsalted butter that has been melted and
cooled to room temperature you don't
want this to be too hot otherwise it's
gonna curdle in your buttermilk here and
then just mix this up you guys and in a
few seconds here you have your wet
ingredients and your dry ingredients
ready for your cornbread and now we're
gonna just combine the wet and the dry
ingredients now if you wanted to change
this batter up and add a little bit more
flavor you could add some chopped up
jalapenos that would be fantastic a
sharp cheddar cheese would be really
great it's gonna add a nice cheesy
flavor but also it's gonna be a little
bit more moist your cornbread some corn
kernels either fresh corn here or if you
had frozen corn that would be really
great tossed in and if you like a little
bit of spice but not jalapeno you can
add a little bit of cayenne pepper
it's kind of up to you and what your
preference is with cornbread and how you
would want to see this doctored up maybe
even a little bit of herbs would be
fantastic but today I'm just gonna do a
simple all-purpose cornbread and I'm
going to pour in my wet ingredients and
then mix this together ever so slightly
you guys you really don't want to
overwork this otherwise your cornbread
is gonna be really tough so if there are
a few lumps in your batter here that's
totally fine now make sure your oven is
preheated to 400 degrees with the rack
in the middle of the oven I'm using a
nine-inch square baking pan
that has been buttered and lined with
parchment now if you had a specific type
of baking pan you wanted to make these
in whether it's a muffin tin to create
individual portions you could certainly
do that or in little cast-iron skillets
that would be fantastic as well you just
have to watch the baking time on them so
this goes into that 400 degree oven for
20 to 25 minutes and it will get a light
golden brown color and then you want to
remove it to a wire rack to cool
completely so I'm just gonna spread this
out into the corners and get it right
into the oven because as you can see
it's already starting to leaven with
that baking soda and buttermilk reacting
so I want to make sure that this gets
nice and fluffy so I'm gonna get it
right into the oven so it can bake up
alright guys so the cornbread has cooled
completely when it comes out of the oven
you want to make sure you let it cool
slightly in the pan before you remove it
and let it cool completely again now I'm
gonna just remove the parchment from the
bottom here and this recipe you guys is
really fantastic not just for eating as
an accompaniment to your bowl of chili
or on your Thanksgiving table but this
could also be used because it has such a
great texture for stuffings as well for
a cornbread stuffing it's not gonna
completely get mushy and all crumbly it
still has a good amount of texture so it
will create a delicious cornbread
stuffing or dressing so I'm just cutting
these into squares here I'm getting
about 16 but again you can cut this into
whatever size pieces you want it has a
lovely texture to it you can see that it
has a nice fluffy texture but it still
has some structure to it
arrange it on a platter serve it with a
